awd_titl_txt: Ergodicity, Rigidity, and the Interplay Between Chaotic and Regular Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
The aim of this project is to discover new phenomena in the area of dynamical systems.  Dynamical systems ("dynamics," for short) is the study of motion, and in particular motion that is dictated by an unchanging set of rules, such as the Newtonian forces controlling mechanical motion.  Well-known experimental phenomena in dynamics such as chaotic trajectories combined with stable motion have been observed experimentally but are far from being fully understood from a theoretical perspective. The research will address the theoretical mechanisms behind chaotic motion in broad classes of dynamical systems, which include systems of both a physical and geometric nature.  Based on previous work of the principal investigator and her collaborators, the interplay between a numerical invariant called entropy and chaotic motion will be further understood. On the flip side, the principal investigator proposes several problems connecting entropy and related invariants with a phenomenon called rigidity.  Rigidity occurs when quantitatively small changes to the rules guiding a system force fundamental qualitative changes in the resulting dynamics. Identifying the rigid systems is a first step toward classification of certain peculiar dynamical behaviors observed in physical and geometric systems. An important aspect of the project is to further interaction between mathematical and adjacent scientific communities, such as physics.  The principal investigator has already collaborated in questions surrounding the design of particle accelerators and is currently collaborating with a physicist studying the quantum dynamics behind the emergence of black holes.  Furthermore, the principal investigator has given several public lectures on dynamics and has written in the popular press about the work of mathematicians. She proposes to expand these activities in the coming years.

Dynamics is the study of systems (for example, a state space for a physical process) that evolve over time according to a deterministic set of rules.  Well-studied classes of such dynamical systems include the so-called hyperbolic systems, which display chaotic, unpredictable features at every point, and KAM systems, which have stable regions of regular motion.  The partially hyperbolic systems are a more general class of dynamical systems than the hyperbolic class and include systems that combine hyperbolicity in some directions with KAM behavior in other directions.  Partially hyperbolic systems occur widely in dynamical systems arising in physics; for example, planetary motion usually contains partially hyperbolic sub-dynamics, and the effective construction of particle accelerators (used in biological imaging, as well as theoretical physics) requires a detailed understanding of both KAM and partially hyperbolic dynamics. The principal investigator has a well-developed research plan of over 15 years studying partially hyperbolic systems and is poised to raise the theory of these systems to a new level of generality and applicability.  The impacts of this research will be seen in future applications to systems of a concrete origin, in biology, physics and engineering.  The principal investigator is currently collaborating with the particle accelerator group at Fermilab to explore some of these potential applications. The research supported by this award is guided by the far-reaching goal of developing a general theory of partially hyperbolic systems along the lines of the hyperbolic theory developed in the past 40 years.  In particular the principal investigator proposes to study: ergodic properties of conservative partially hyperbolic diffeomorphisms; actions of large collections of diffeomorphisms and embeddings on manifolds; and rigidity phenomena in actions of groups.  A highlight of the proposed research is to investigate the interaction between hyperbolicity and KAM phenomena.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this project was to explore fundamental questions in smooth dynamics, focusing on how chaotic and regular behaviors coexist and influence each other in various mathematical systems. Specifically, the research addressed themes of ergodicity (where a system evolves in such a way that its behavior averages out over time), rigidity (where certain properties of a system remain unchanged under perturbation), and the transition between chaotic and regular dynamics. The project led to significant advancements in our understanding of these phenomena, with contributions that address both the intellectual merit and broader impacts as outlined by the NSF.

Intellectual Merit

Over the life of the award, the research produced several important findings in smooth dynamics. One major outcome was the development of new techniques for studying partially hyperbolic systems—systems that exhibit both chaotic and regular behavior. In particular, we proved that certain types of dynamical systems with mixed behaviors can exhibit stability under small perturbations.  We also contributed to a long-standing problem in the field known as the $C^1$ ergodic hypothesis. These results show that for a large class of dynamical systems, chaotic behavior can persist and even be the "typical" outcome.

Another key contribution was in the area of rigidity. The project established new connections between the symmetries of dynamical systems and their long-term behavior. For example, we classified diffeomorphisms (smooth transformations of geometric spaces) with "large" symmetry groups, showing that these symmetries often impose strong constraints on how the system behaves. This work contributes to a broader understanding of how certain dynamical systems can be uniquely characterized by their symmetries, even when they are subject to small changes.

Publications stemming from this project advanced the theory of smooth dynamics, particularly in the areas of stable ergodicity, the dynamics of foliations (decompositions of space into simpler, lower-dimensional objects), and rigidity in smooth systems. These results have broad applications in mathematics, including in fields such as ergodic theory and statistical mechanics, and they help deepen our understanding of how complex systems evolve over time.

Broader Impacts

In addition to the intellectual contributions, the project had several broader impacts. A significant focus was placed on mentoring and outreach activities. During the reporting period, the PI supervised the research of 3 Ph.D. dissertations and the research of several postdoctoral fellows. This not only contributed to the development of the next generation of researchers but also ensured that the techniques and findings from this project are passed on to younger scientists who will continue to explore these important areas of mathematics.

The project also engaged with underrepresented communities in mathematics. As a board member of the Math Circles of Chicago, the PI helped to bring engaging mathematical activities to underserved communities, promoting inclusivity in the field. Additionally, the PI wrote an autobiographical essay about her experiences as a woman in mathematics, which has helped to raise awareness of the challenges and opportunities faced by underrepresented groups in STEM fields.

Finally, public engagement has been a key part of the broader impacts of this award. The delivered several high-profile lectures, including the AMS Erdös Memorial Lecture, and participated in podcasts and interviews that helped to disseminate complex mathematical ideas to a broader audience. These efforts have contributed to a wider appreciation of the beauty and importance of mathematics, particularly in understanding complex, chaotic systems that impact real-world applications.

In summary, this award has led to significant advancements in the field of smooth dynamics and has had broad impacts through mentorship, outreach, and public engagement. The findings from this project have not only deepened our understanding of chaotic and regular dynamics but have also helped to shape future research directions in this critical area of mathematics.
